sn22.3:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā mahākaccāno avantīsu viharati kuraraghare papāte pabbate.
sn22.3:1.2.eng: At one time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying in the land of the Avantis near Kuraraghara on Steep Mountain.
sn22.3:1.2.comm: Mahākaccāna was one of the great disciples, whose teachings specially emphasized the incisive analysis of consciousness through the lens of the six senses. He was said to be the most skilled at given detailed explanations of brief teachings (AN 1.197), a skill he displayed also at MN 133, MN 138, and AN 10.172. He settled to the southwest in Avanti, where he established the Dhamma in the region; see SN 35.132 and notes..

sn22.3:1.3.pli: Atha kho hāliddikāni gahapati yenāyasmā mahākaccāno tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ mahākaccānaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho hāliddikāni gahapati āyasmantaṃ mahākaccānaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.3:1.3.eng: Then the householder Hāliddikāni went up to Venerable Mahākaccāna, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
sn22.3:1.3.comm: Hāliddikāni was a learned lay student of Mahākaccāna in Avanti (SN 22.4, SN 35.130). | From this point, the discourse is quoted in full at Mnd 9:70.1 as a commentary on the verse. This underscores the fact that even within the Suttas themselves, there are many passages that can be considered commentaries on earlier discourses.

sn22.3:1.4.eng: “Sir, this was said by the Buddha in the Chapter of the Eights, in ‘The Questions of Māgandiya’:

sn22.3:2.1.eng: ‘After leaving their bastion to migrate without abode,
sn22.3:2.1.comm: This line works perfectly well at the literal level, the life of a homeless renunciate. But Mahākaccāna reveals a metaphorical dimension, which pivots on the fact that the suffix sārī (“migrate”) has the same root as saṁsāra (“transmigration”). | Oka is an old Vedic word for “home” (Rig Veda 5.76.4) for people, gods, or even cows (RV 6.41.1) with connotations of safety and refuge from which one might be driven out by a foe (RV 7.5.6).

sn22.3:2.2.eng: a sage doesn’t get close to anyone in town.

sn22.3:2.3.eng: Rid of sensual pleasures, not expecting,

sn22.3:2.4.eng: they wouldn’t get in arguments with people.’

sn22.3:3.1.pli: Imassa nu kho, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa kathaṃ vitthārena attho daṭṭhabbo”ti?
sn22.3:3.1.eng: How should we see the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement?”

sn22.3:4.1.eng: “Householder, the form element is a shelter for consciousness.
sn22.3:4.1.comm: Note the use of dhātu (“element”) instead of khandha (“aggregate”). Also at SN 22.4, SN 22.45, SN 22.53–5.

sn22.3:4.2.eng: One whose consciousness is shackled by greed for the form element is called a migrant going from bastion to bastion.
sn22.3:4.2.comm: They wander from life to life, like “people entering and leaving a house, walking along the streets and paths, and sitting at the central square” (DN 2:96.1, MN 39:20.3). As in dependent origination, “consciousness” is key to transmigration as the link from one life to the next (SN 12.38–40).

sn22.3:4.3.eng: The feeling element is a shelter for consciousness.

sn22.3:4.4.eng: One whose consciousness is shackled to greed for the feeling element is called a migrant going from bastion to bastion.

sn22.3:4.5.eng: The perception element is a shelter for consciousness.

sn22.3:4.6.eng: One whose consciousness is shackled to greed for the perception element is called a migrant going from bastion to bastion.

sn22.3:4.7.eng: The choices element is a shelter for consciousness.

sn22.3:4.8.eng: One whose consciousness is shackled to greed for the choices element is called a migrant going from bastion to bastion.

sn22.3:4.9.eng: That’s how one is a migrant going from  bastion to bastion.

sn22.3:5.1.eng: And how is one a migrant with no bastion?

sn22.3:5.2.pli: Rūpadhātuyā kho, gahapati, yo chando yo rāgo yā nandī yā taṇhā ye upayupādānā cetaso adhiṭṭhānābhinivesānusayā te tathāgatassa pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
sn22.3:5.2.eng: The Realized One has given up any desire, greed, relishing, and craving for the form element; any attraction, grasping, mental fixation, insistence, and underlying tendencies. He has cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.

sn22.3:5.3.eng: That’s why the Realized One is called a migrant with no bastion.

sn22.3:5.4.eng: The Realized One has given up any desire, greed, relishing, and craving for the feeling element …

sn22.3:5.7.pli: viññāṇadhātuyā kho, gahapati, yo chando yo rāgo yā nandī yā taṇhā ye upayupādānā cetaso adhiṭṭhānābhinivesānusayā te tathāgatassa pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
sn22.3:5.7.eng: the consciousness element; any attraction, grasping, mental fixation, insistence, and underlying tendencies. He has cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.

sn22.3:5.8.eng: That’s why the Realized One is called a migrant with no bastion.

sn22.3:5.9.eng: That’s how one is a migrant with no shelter.

sn22.3:6.1.eng: And how is one a migrant going from abode to abode?
sn22.3:6.1.comm: The commentary explains the difference between “bastion” (oka) and “abode” (niketa) as one of degree. A bastion is a place where one is established in comfort and safety and is thus tightly attached as to the aggregates. An abode is any old place one might stay, and are therefore lightly attached to, like the passing parade of sense experiences.

sn22.3:6.2.eng: Shackled to chasing the abodes that are the features of sights, one is called a migrant going from abode to abode.
sn22.3:6.2.comm: Pali visāra seems unique (at DN 13:36.2 read visāda). Here it is clearly connected to sārī in the sense of “migrant”, as well as anusārī in the phrase rūpanimittānusāri (“follows after the features of that sight”, MN 138:10.2). I take it as an intensive form of “follow”, i.e. “chase”.

sn22.3:6.3.eng: Shackled to chasing the abodes that are the features of sounds …

sn22.3:6.7.eng: thoughts, one is called a migrant going from abode to abode.

sn22.3:6.8.eng: That’s how one is a migrant going from abode to abode.

sn22.3:7.1.eng: And how is one a migrant without abode?

sn22.3:7.2.pli: Rūpanimittaniketavisāravinibandhā kho, gahapati, tathāgatassa pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
sn22.3:7.2.eng: The Realized One has given up chasing the abodes that are the features of  sights. He has cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.

sn22.3:7.3.eng: That’s why the Realized One is called a migrant without abode.

sn22.3:7.4.eng: The Realized One has given up chasing the abodes that are the features of sounds …

sn22.3:7.8.pli: dhammanimittaniketavisāravinibandhā kho, gahapati, tathāgatassa pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
sn22.3:7.8.eng: ideas. He has cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.

sn22.3:7.9.eng: That’s why the Realized One is called a migrant without abode.

sn22.3:7.10.eng: That’s how one is a migrant without abode.

sn22.3:8.1.eng: And how does one get close to people in town?

sn22.3:8.2.pli: Idha, gahapati, ekacco gihīhi saṃsaṭṭho viharati sahanandī sahasokī, sukhitesu sukhito, dukkhitesu dukkhito, uppannesu kiccakaraṇīyesu attanā tesu yogaṃ āpajjati.
sn22.3:8.2.eng: It’s when someone mixes closely with laypeople, sharing their joys and sorrows—happy when they’re happy and sad when they’re sad—and getting themselves involved in their business.

sn22.3:8.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, gahapati, gāme santhavajāto hoti.
sn22.3:8.3.eng: That’s how one gets close to people in town.

sn22.3:9.1.pli: Kathañca, gahapati, gāme na santhavajāto hoti?
sn22.3:9.1.eng: And how does one not get close to people in town?

sn22.3:9.2.pli: Idha, gahapati, bhikkhu gihīhi asaṃsaṭṭho viharati na sahanandī na sahasokī na sukhitesu sukhito na dukkhitesu dukkhito, uppannesu kiccakaraṇīyesu na attanā tesu yogaṃ āpajjati.
sn22.3:9.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t mix closely with laypeople, not sharing their joys and sorrows—not happy when they’re happy or sad when they’re sad—and not getting themselves involved in their business.

sn22.3:9.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, gahapati, gāme na santhavajāto hoti.
sn22.3:9.3.eng: That’s how one doesn’t get close to people in town.

sn22.3:10.1.eng: And how is one not rid of sensual pleasures?

sn22.3:10.2.pli: Idha, gahapati, ekacco kāmesu avigatarāgo hoti avigatacchando avigatapemo avigatapipāso avigatapariḷāho avigatataṇho.
sn22.3:10.2.eng: It’s when someone isn’t rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.

sn22.3:10.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, gahapati, kāmehi aritto hoti.
sn22.3:10.3.eng: That’s how one is not rid of sensual pleasures.

sn22.3:11.1.eng: And how is one rid of sensual pleasures?

sn22.3:11.2.pli: Idha, gahapati, ekacco kāmesu vigatarāgo hoti vigatacchando vigatapemo vigatapipāso vigatapariḷāho vigatataṇho.
sn22.3:11.2.eng: It’s when someone is rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.

sn22.3:11.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, gahapati, kāmehi ritto hoti.
sn22.3:11.3.eng: That’s how one is rid of sensual pleasures.

sn22.3:12.3.pli: ‘evaṃrūpo siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ, evaṃvedano siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ, evaṃsañño siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ, evaṃsaṅkhāro siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ, evaṃviññāṇo siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānan’ti.
sn22.3:12.3.eng: ‘In the future, may I be of such form, such feeling, such perception, such choices, and such consciousness!’

sn22.3:13.1.eng: And how is one not expecting?

sn22.3:13.2.pli: Idha, gahapati, ekaccassa na evaṃ hoti:

sn22.3:13.3.pli: ‘evaṃrūpo siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ, evaṃvedano siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ, evaṃsañño siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ, evaṃsaṅkhāro siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ, evaṃviññāṇo siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānan’ti.
sn22.3:13.3.eng: ‘In the future, may I be of such form, such feeling, such perception, such choices, and such consciousness!’

sn22.3:13.4.eng: That’s how one is not expecting.

sn22.3:14.1.pli: Kathañca, gahapati, kathaṃ viggayha janena kattā hoti?
sn22.3:14.1.eng: And how does one argue with people?

sn22.3:14.2.pli: Idha, gahapati, ekacco evarūpiṃ kathaṃ kattā hoti:
sn22.3:14.2.eng: It’s when someone takes part in this sort of discussion:

sn22.3:14.3.pli: ‘na tvaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānāsi; ahaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānāmi. Kiṃ tvaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānissasi? Micchāpaṭipanno tvamasi; ahamasmi sammāpaṭipanno. Pure vacanīyaṃ pacchā avaca; pacchā vacanīyaṃ pure avaca. Sahitaṃ me, asahitaṃ te. Adhiciṇṇaṃ te viparāvattaṃ. Āropito te vādo; cara vādappamokkhāya. Niggahitosi; nibbeṭhehi vā sace pahosī’ti.
sn22.3:14.3.eng: ‘You don’t understand this teaching and training. I understand this teaching and training. What, you understand this teaching and training? You’re practicing wrong. I’m practicing right. You said last what you should have said first. You said first what you should have said last. I stay on topic, you don’t. What you’ve thought so much about has been disproved. Your doctrine is refuted. Go on, save your doctrine! You’re trapped; get yourself out of this—if you can!’
sn22.3:14.3.comm: Sahita (“on topic”) appears routinely as a quality of a good Dhamma talk (eg. AN 4.139:3.2, AN 8.16:1.3). It has the basic sense of “collected, bundled” (like firewood, DN 23:21.49), in which sense it appears in Sanskrit as saṁhita, the name of the “bundled” collection of Vedic scripture.

sn22.3:14.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, gahapati, kathaṃ viggayha janena kattā hoti.
sn22.3:14.4.eng: That’s how one argues with people.

sn22.3:15.1.pli: Kathañca, gahapati, kathaṃ na viggayha janena kattā hoti?
sn22.3:15.1.eng: And how does one not argue with people?

sn22.3:15.2.pli: Idha, gahapati, bhikkhu na evarūpiṃ kathaṃ kattā hoti:
sn22.3:15.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t take part in this sort of discussion:

sn22.3:15.3.pli: ‘na tvaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānāsi …pe… nibbeṭhehi vā sace pahosī’ti.
sn22.3:15.3.eng: ‘You don’t understand this teaching and training … get yourself out of this—if you can!’

sn22.3:15.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, gahapati, kathaṃ na viggayha janena kattā hoti.
sn22.3:15.4.eng: That’s how one doesn’t argue with people.

sn22.3:16.1.pli: Iti kho, gahapati, yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā aṭṭhakavaggiye māgaṇḍiyapañhe:
sn22.3:16.1.eng: So, householder, that’s how to understand the detailed meaning of what the Buddha said in brief in the Chapter of the Eights, in ‘The Questions of Māgandiya’:

sn22.3:17.1.eng: ‘After leaving their bastion to migrate without abode,

sn22.3:17.2.eng: a sage doesn’t get close to anyone in town.

sn22.3:17.3.eng: Rid of sensual pleasures, not expecting,

sn22.3:17.4.eng: they wouldn’t get in arguments with people.’”

sn22.3:18.1.pli: Imassa kho, gahapati, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena attho daṭṭhabbo”ti.

sn22.30:1.2.pli: “Yo, bhikkhave, rūpassa uppādo ṭhiti abhinibbatti pātubhāvo, dukkhasseso uppādo rogānaṃ ṭhiti jarāmaraṇassa pātubhāvo.
sn22.30:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, the arising, continuation, and manifestation and regeneration of form is the arising of suffering, the continuation of diseases, and the manifestation of old age and death.

sn22.30:1.3.eng: The arising, continuation, and manifestation and regeneration of feeling …

sn22.30:1.6.pli: yo viññāṇassa uppādo ṭhiti abhinibbatti pātubhāvo, dukkhasseso uppādo rogānaṃ ṭhiti jarāmaraṇassa pātubhāvo.
sn22.30:1.6.eng: consciousness is the arising of suffering, the continuation of diseases, and the manifestation of old age and death.

sn22.30:1.7.pli: Yo ca kho, bhikkhave, rūpassa nirodho vūpasamo atthaṅgamo, dukkhasseso nirodho rogānaṃ vūpasamo jarāmaraṇassa atthaṅgamo.
sn22.30:1.7.eng: The cessation, settling, and disappearance of form is the cessation of suffering, the settling of diseases, and the disappearance of old age and death.

sn22.30:1.8.eng: The cessation, settling, and ending of feeling …

sn22.30:1.11.pli: yo viññāṇassa nirodho vūpasamo atthaṅgamo, dukkhasseso nirodho rogānaṃ vūpasamo jarāmaraṇassa atthaṅgamo”ti.
sn22.30:1.11.eng: consciousness is the cessation of suffering, the settling of diseases, and the disappearance of old age and death.”

sn22.31:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you gloom and the root of gloom.
sn22.31:1.2.comm: “Gloom” (agha) seems to have originally had the sense of “darkness, void”, a name for the black, starless reaches of space (MN 123:7.4; cf. Rig Veda 10.85.13, for which read “blacknesses”). Legend depicts Agha as a vast serpent of foul-smelling, cave-like maw who devours the innocent. Hence the black evil of agha is driven away by the blazing fire (Rig Veda 1.97). But whereas the Vedic usage associates agha with evil, malignant deeds—and hence the second noble truth, that which perpetuates suffering—in Buddhism it is associated with the first noble truth, suffering itself.

sn22.31:1.5.pli: Rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, aghaṃ, vedanā aghaṃ, saññā aghaṃ, saṅkhārā aghaṃ, viññāṇaṃ aghaṃ.
sn22.31:1.5.eng: Form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are gloom.

sn22.31:1.7.eng: And what is the root of gloom?

sn22.31:1.8.eng: It’s the craving that leads to future lives, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure wherever it lands. That is,

sn22.31:1.9.eng: craving for sensual pleasures, craving for existence, and craving for nonexistence.

sn22.31:1.10.eng: This is called the root of gloom.”

sn22.32:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you what is brittle and what is not brittle.
sn22.32:1.2.comm: “Brittle” (pabhaṅgu) like gold corrupted by impurities and hence unworkable (SN 46.33:1.8).

sn22.32:1.4.eng: And what is brittle? What is not brittle?

sn22.32:1.6.pli: Yo tassa nirodho vūpasamo atthaṅgamo, idaṃ appabhaṅgu.
sn22.32:1.6.eng: but its cessation, settling, and ending is not brittle.

sn22.32:1.8.pli: Yo tassā nirodho vūpasamo atthaṅgamo, idaṃ appabhaṅgu.

sn22.32:1.11.pli: Yo tesaṃ nirodho vūpasamo atthaṅgamo, idaṃ appabhaṅgu.

sn22.32:1.13.pli: Yo tassa nirodho vūpasamo atthaṅgamo, idaṃ appabhaṅgū”ti.
sn22.32:1.13.eng: but its cessation, settling, and ending is not brittle.”

sn22.33:1.2.comm: This trope is also found at MN 22:40.1, SN 35.101:1.1, etc.

sn22.33:1.3.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.
sn22.33:1.3.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn22.33:1.5.pli: Rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, na tumhākaṃ, taṃ pajahatha.
sn22.33:1.5.eng: Form isn’t yours: give it up.

sn22.33:1.6.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.
sn22.33:1.6.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn22.33:1.8.pli: Sā vo pahīnā hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.

sn22.33:1.11.pli: Te vo pahīnā hitāya sukhāya bhavissanti.

sn22.33:1.12.eng: Consciousness isn’t yours: give it up.

sn22.33:1.13.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.
sn22.33:1.13.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn22.33:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yaṃ imasmiṃ jetavane tiṇakaṭṭhasākhāpalāsaṃ taṃ jano hareyya vā ḍaheyya vā yathāpaccayaṃ vā kareyya.
sn22.33:2.1.eng: Suppose a person was to carry off the grass, sticks, branches, and leaves in this Jeta’s Grove, or burn them, or do what they want with them.

sn22.33:2.3.pli: ‘amhe jano harati vā ḍahati vā yathāpaccayaṃ vā karotī’”ti?
sn22.33:2.3.eng: ‘This person is carrying us off, burning us, or doing what they want with us’?”

sn22.33:2.6.pli: “Na hi no etaṃ, bhante, attā vā attaniyaṃ vā”ti.
sn22.33:2.6.eng: Because to us that’s neither self nor belonging to self.”

sn22.33:2.7.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ na tumhākaṃ, taṃ pajahatha.
sn22.33:2.7.eng: “In the same way, mendicants, form isn’t yours: give it up.

sn22.33:2.8.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.
sn22.33:2.8.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn22.33:2.10.pli: Sā vo pahīnā hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.

sn22.33:2.13.eng: Consciousness isn’t yours: give it up.

sn22.33:2.14.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissatī”ti.
sn22.33:2.14.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.”

sn22.34:1.3.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.
sn22.34:1.3.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn22.34:1.5.pli: Rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, na tumhākaṃ, taṃ pajahatha.
sn22.34:1.5.eng: Form isn’t yours: give it up.

sn22.34:1.6.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.
sn22.34:1.6.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn22.34:1.10.eng: Consciousness isn’t yours: give it up.

sn22.34:1.11.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.
sn22.34:1.11.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn22.34:1.12.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, na tumhākaṃ taṃ pajahatha.

sn22.34:1.13.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissatī”ti.
sn22.34:1.13.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.”

sn22.35:1.2.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.35:1.2.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

sn22.35:1.3.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetu;
sn22.35:1.3.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”
sn22.35:1.3.comm: The idea of a “retreat” as understood today was popularized in the 20th century. In early times, it seems, when an individual monastic felt they were ready, they would approach the teacher seeking advice before entering seclusion for an extended period of meditation.

sn22.35:1.4.pli: yamahaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā eko vūpakaṭṭho, appamatto ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.

sn22.35:1.5.pli: “Yaṃ kho, bhikkhu, anuseti, tena saṅkhaṃ gacchati;
sn22.35:1.5.eng: “Mendicant, you’re reckoned by what you have an underlying tendency for.
sn22.35:1.5.comm: Saṅkhā is a calculation or measurement or “reckoning”. The idea is that we define and limit ourselves by our attachments. | The “underlying tendencies” or “inherent compulsions” are classically numbered as seven (SN 45.175), or else may be a general term for fundamental defilements (SN 36.3).

sn22.35:1.6.pli: yaṃ nānuseti, na tena saṅkhaṃ gacchatī”ti.
sn22.35:1.6.eng: You’re not reckoned by what you have no underlying tendency for.”

sn22.35:2.1.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāsī”ti?
sn22.35:2.1.eng: “But how do you see the detailed meaning of my brief statement?”

sn22.35:2.2.eng: “If you have an underlying tendency for form, you’re reckoned by that.

sn22.35:2.3.eng: If you have an underlying tendency for feeling …

sn22.35:2.5.pli: Saṅkhāre ce anuseti tena saṅkhaṃ gacchati.

sn22.35:2.7.pli: Rūpañce, bhante, nānuseti na tena saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
sn22.35:2.7.eng: If you have no underlying tendency for form, you’re not reckoned by that.

sn22.35:2.8.eng: If you have no underlying tendency for feeling …

sn22.35:2.11.pli: viññāṇañce nānuseti na tena saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
sn22.35:2.11.eng: consciousness, you’re not reckoned by that.

sn22.35:2.12.pli: Imassa khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmī”ti.
sn22.35:2.12.eng: That’s how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.”

sn22.35:3.2.pli: Sādhu kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāsi.
sn22.35:3.2.eng: It’s good that you understand the detailed meaning of what I’ve said in brief like this.

sn22.35:3.3.pli: Rūpañce, bhikkhu, anuseti tena saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
sn22.35:3.3.eng: If you have an underlying tendency for form, you’re reckoned by that.

sn22.35:3.4.eng: If you have an underlying tendency for feeling …

sn22.35:3.8.pli: Rūpañce, bhikkhu, nānuseti na tena saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
sn22.35:3.8.eng: If you have no underlying tendency for form, you’re not reckoned by that.

sn22.35:3.9.eng: If you have no underlying tendency for feeling …

sn22.35:3.12.pli: viññāṇañce nānuseti na tena saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
sn22.35:3.12.eng: consciousness, you’re not reckoned by that.

sn22.35:3.13.pli: Imassa kho, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhittena, bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena attho daṭṭhabbo”ti.
sn22.35:3.13.eng: This is how to understand the detailed meaning of what I said in brief.”

sn22.35:4.1.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
sn22.35:4.1.eng: And then that mendicant approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

sn22.35:5.1.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
sn22.35:5.1.eng: Then that mendicant, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

sn22.35:5.2.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
sn22.35:5.2.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

sn22.35:5.3.pli: Aññataro ca pana so bhikkhu arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn22.35:5.3.eng: And that mendicant became one of the perfected.

sn22.36:1.2.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.36:1.2.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha … and asked him,

sn22.36:1.3.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetu yamahaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.
sn22.36:1.3.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

sn22.36:1.4.eng: “Mendicant, you’re measured against what you have an underlying tendency for,

sn22.36:1.5.eng: and you’re reckoned by what you’re measured against.

sn22.36:1.6.eng: You’re not measured against what you have no underlying tendency for,

sn22.36:1.7.pli: yaṃ nānumīyati na tena saṅkhaṃ gacchatī”ti.
sn22.36:1.7.eng: and you’re not reckoned by what you’re not measured against.”

sn22.36:2.1.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāsī”ti?
sn22.36:2.1.eng: “But how do you see the detailed meaning of my brief statement?”

sn22.36:2.2.eng: “If you have an underlying tendency for form, you’re measured against that,

sn22.36:2.3.eng: and you’re reckoned by what you’re measured against.

sn22.36:2.4.eng: If you have an underlying tendency for feeling …

sn22.36:2.8.eng: and you’re reckoned by what you’re measured against.

sn22.36:2.9.pli: Rūpañce, bhante, nānuseti na taṃ anumīyati;
sn22.36:2.9.eng: If you have no underlying tendency for form, you’re not measured against that,

sn22.36:2.10.pli: yaṃ nānumīyati na tena saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
sn22.36:2.10.eng: and you’re not reckoned by what you’re not measured against.

sn22.36:2.11.eng: If you have no underlying tendency for feeling …

sn22.36:2.14.eng: consciousness, you’re not measured against that,

sn22.36:2.15.pli: yaṃ nānumīyati na tena saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
sn22.36:2.15.eng: and you’re not reckoned by what you’re not measured against.

sn22.36:2.16.pli: Imassa khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmī”ti.
sn22.36:2.16.eng: That’s how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.”

sn22.36:3.2.pli: Sādhu kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāsi.
sn22.36:3.2.eng: It’s good that you understand the detailed meaning of what I’ve said in brief like this.

sn22.36:3.3.eng: If you have an underlying tendency for form, you’re measured against that,

sn22.36:3.4.eng: and you’re reckoned by what you’re measured against.

sn22.36:3.5.eng: If you have an underlying tendency for feeling …

sn22.36:3.9.eng: and you’re reckoned by what you’re measured against.

sn22.36:3.10.pli: Rūpañce, bhikkhu, nānuseti na taṃ anumīyati;
sn22.36:3.10.eng: If you have no underlying tendency for form, you’re not measured against that,

sn22.36:3.11.pli: yaṃ nānumīyati na tena saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
sn22.36:3.11.eng: and you’re not reckoned by what you’re not measured against.

sn22.36:3.12.eng: If you have no underlying tendency for feeling …

sn22.36:3.15.eng: consciousness, you’re not measured against that,

sn22.36:3.16.pli: yaṃ nānumīyati na tena saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
sn22.36:3.16.eng: and you’re not reckoned by what you’re not measured against.

sn22.36:3.17.pli: Imassa kho, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena attho daṭṭhabbo”ti …pe…
sn22.36:3.17.eng: This is how to understand the detailed meaning of what I said in brief.” …

sn22.36:3.18.pli: aññataro ca pana so bhikkhu arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn22.36:3.18.eng: And that mendicant became one of the perfected.
